#Text=False dawn for Air France flight ; debris not from crash , search continues
#Text=Friday , June 5 , 2009
#Text=File : Busca voo Air France 447
#Text=1 . jpg
#Text=A view from the cockpit of a Brazilian plane searching for the flight .
#Text=Image : Johnson Barros , Brazilian Air Force .
#Text=( Image missing from commons : image ; log )
#Text=Teams from France and Brazil have confirmed that neither have recovered any debris from Air France Flight 447 .
#Text=The Airbus A330 with 228 on board vanished from radar on June 1st over the Atlantic Ocean .
#Text=The Brazilian Air Force had previously released a statement on June 2 saying debris from the lost jet had been found .
#Text=A wooden cargo pallet and two buoys had been recovered , but are now believed to have been from a ship .
#Text=The flight was carrying no wooden pallets .
#Text=On June 2 , it was reported , and previously confirmed by the Brazilian Air Force , that one seat and a life vest were found floating in the water .
#Text=An Air France A330 similar to the missing airliner .
#Text=Image : Christopher Weyer .
#Text=A fuel slick also thought to be from the plane , has also been confirmed to have come from another source , most likely a ship .
#Text=The presence of fuel was used as evidence to suggest there had been no fire or explosion on board .
#Text=Spanish paper El Mundo has quoted an Air Comet pilot flying over the Atlantic at the time as saying he witnessed " an intense burst of white light " falling out of the sky and breaking apart .

#Text=A bomb threat , which later turned out to be " false " , was also reported on a separate Air France flight from Buenos Aires , Argentina to Paris on May 27 , just days before Fight 447 went missing .

#Text=The French Bureau of Enquiry and Analysis for Civil Aviation Safety ( BEA ) is leading the investigation , and has so far established that there were thunderstorms in the area and a series of automated signals from the plane indicated an inconsistent speed and a string of systems failures .
#Text=The French research vessel Pourquoi pas ? is carrying mini-submarines to the search area .
#Text=Image : Zubro .
#Text=At 11:10 p.m.
#Text=the autopilot disengaged and at least one computer switched to an alternative power source .

#Text=There was an indication that flight control systems had sustained damage , and this was followed by the failure of speed , heading and altitude indicators as well as flight control systems , while control systems for the central computer system and wing spoilers also failed .
#Text=Four minutes after the problems began the last message indicated total electrical failure and a loss of cabin pressure .
#Text=French armed forces spokesman Christophe Prazuck commented that " Everyone has doubts about everything at the moment and we do not have the slightest beginnings of an answer yet . "
#Text=French paper Le Monde commented that the aircraft 's speed was too low , prompting the BEA to warn against " hasty interpretation or speculation " in regards to the cause .
#Text=Airbus have reminded all A330 operators of correct operating procedures in extreme weather conditions .
#Text=France has sent the research ship Pourquoi Pas ? to the scene and the vessel is currently en route with mini-submarines to assist in searching for and recovering debris .
#Text=The search is still underway for the plane 's cockpit voice and flight data recorders , or black boxes .
#Text=Brazilian officials previously said the boxes could be at the bottom of the ocean , between " 2,000 or 3,000 metres [ 6,500 to 9,800 feet ] in that area of the ocean . "
